image.altText: A facebook post by Launceston mayor Matthew Garwood

props.synopsis: The mayor of Tasmania's second-largest city has hit back online at critics after posting to social media about "mic drop moment[s] when I get to play the 'Mayor card,'" while posing with a visiting US rapper and singer who has a history of run-ins with the law.

title.children: Photo with US rapper sparks criticism of Tasmanian mayor

image.altText: A man with medium-length hair wearing a blue t-shirt smiles while sitting on a couch.

props.synopsis: The man who was the "designated driver" in the alleged 2022 home invasion and murder of a Tasmanian man in Sprent has denied planning and instigating the proposed theft.

title.children: Lawyer says third man was 'mastermind' of alleged 2022 murder

image.altText: Grove bus stop 2025-02-25 11:02:00

props.synopsis: The speed limit for a notorious highway intersection in Tasmania's south has been reduced weeks after a 17-year-old student was struck by a car.

title.children: Huon Highway blackspot speed limit drop after boy critically injured

image.altText: Julia Jacklin at Panama Festival

props.synopsis: Another music event has announced it is taking a break, with Tasmania's Panama festival not going ahead in 2026.

title.children: Tasmania's Panama festival won't run in 2026, as founders claim logging threatens site

image.altText: A horse with a harness coach.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian harness racing inquiry has heard allegations of race fixing, illegal betting and horses being given cocaine before race meets. The state's opposition says the allegations should be referred to Tasmania police.

title.children: Horses on cocaine, race fixing among allegations at inquiry

image.altText: Hands clasping at prison cell bars, good generic for prison, detention, jail, confinement

props.synopsis: Right to Information documents show Tasmania's Risdon Prison site was in lockdown more than 6,000 times last year.

title.children: 'You're expecting them not to reoffend?': Ex-inmate decries lockdowns

image.altText: A person uses an autopen to sign a document

props.synopsis: US presidents have been using autopens for decades, but now Donald Trump says Joe Biden's January 6 committee pardons are invalid because they were signed using the device. But what even is an autopen?

title.children: What is an 'autopen' and do Trump's claims about Biden's use of it stack up?

image.altText: Group of city workers walking on street

props.synopsis: A new report from campaign group Everybody's Home finds that Australian renters now need to earn at least $130,000 a year to comfortably afford the national weekly asking rent for a typical unit.

title.children: Even on a $100,000 salary, Australians struggle to afford average rent

image.altText: A damaged plane with black marks after flames.

props.synopsis: A fire that destroyed a South Korean plane prompts closer examination of lithium-ion battery safety, with some airlines starting to change their rules.

title.children: South Korea plane fire likely caused by battery pack, now airlines changing rules

image.altText: Crossbench MPs wear orange pieces of clothing in the house of representatives

props.synopsis: Voters have demonstrated they're not afraid of creating a bit of political disruption to the major parties.

title.children: If we elect a hung parliament, voters are sending a message that can't be ignored

image.altText: a child shovels sand into a plastic bucket

props.synopsis: The call came in the wake of a Four Corners investigation that exposed a flawed, inconsistent regulatory system and an increasingly profit-driven industry that has resulted in some centres cutting corners, hiring unqualified staff and eroding the overall quality of care.

title.children: Prime minister rules out royal commission into childcare sector

image.altText: A child playing with magnetic plastic shapes on a surface. The child's face can't be seen.

props.synopsis: With centres reassessed on average every four years, and some gaming the system, parents cannot be sure their child's centre meets the standards or that staff are properly trained or qualified.

title.children: Australia's childcare rating system labelled 'a joke' as failing centres stay open for years

image.altText: Toyah Cordingley sits with her dogs.

props.synopsis: The 24-year-old health store worker's body was found with a slashed throat and multiple stab wounds on a beach north of Cairns, the court heard.

title.children: Jury in trial of man accused of murdering Toyah Cordingley discharged

image.altText: A blue and grey building with a white sighn with red writing that says Inverell Acquatic Centre

props.synopsis: On a hot Autumn's day, parents in the regional town of Inverell sent their children to the local pool to cool off. Not long after, NSW Police told them to leave.

title.children: Parents outraged at local pool as kids left 'confused' and 'frightened'

image.altText: Man holds rock with fossil fish.

props.synopsis: The serendipitous discovery of exquisitely preserved fossil near Gulgong in NSW provides a glimpse into the evolution of Australian fish around 15 million years ago when the area was a tropical lake.

title.children: Fish fossil discovered in NSW is so well preserved we can see its lunch

image.altText: Jackson Archer lifts his arms up while grimacing

props.synopsis: Kangaroos defender Jackson Archer's three-match suspension was upheld by the AFL tribunal with the league successfully arguing his conduct was "unreasonable in the circumstances".

title.children: Archer loses tribunal case despite victim saying clash was not his fault

image.altText: Main sign outside Magistrates, Supreme and District courts complex in Brisbane's CBD.

props.synopsis: A mother who sexually abused a student from the age of 12 will spend at least the next two years in jail.

title.children: Former teacher transferred schools to continue abusing her female student

props.synopsis: Around the clock coverage of news events as they break at home and abroad.

title.children: ABC News Channel live

image.altText: Lilie James, who was found dead at St Andrew's Cathedral School on October 25, 2023, in 2020 in graduation outfit and hat

props.synopsis: An inquest has begun into the death of Lilie James, who was killed by her former short-term partner, Paul Thijssen, in Sydney's CBD in October 2023.

title.children: Evidence Lilie James's killer 'rehearsed' fatal attack, inquest told

image.altText: An extremely muddy rural property.

props.synopsis: Health authorities are on high alert after another melioidosis death in North Queensland amid fears the disease is occurring in places where it was previously all but unheard of.

title.children: Melioidosis death toll hits 20 in Queensland as more rain forecast

image.altText: Chinese flag with cattle

props.synopsis: Hundreds of abattoirs in the United States appear to have had their export licences to China extended in a last-minute update by China customs. But questions remain for the beef trade.

title.children: US meat exports to China get last-minute extension, but beef in limbo

image.altText: green egg carton with one single egg

props.synopsis: Egg shortages are predicted to continue for at least three years. We look at substitutes you can use to keep things moving in your kitchen.

title.children: Egg shortages are predicted for the next three years. Here are some substitutes

image.altText: Deanna Coates eyes are seen in the rearview mirror of her car, with red car tail lights visible in front.

props.synopsis: While most of Australia is sleeping, more than 1 million workers are supporting the $174 billion night-time economy.

title.children: While we are sleeping, 1 million workers make up Australia's night economy

image.altText: The white SpaceX Dragon shuttle undocking from the underbelly of the International Space Station

props.synopsis: After nine months stranded in space, Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams have taken off in a SpaceX capsule bound for Earth. Follow live.

title.children: 'Crew 9 is going home': Stranded astronauts begin journey back to Earth

image.altText: Four men and one woman, all wearing suits, walk in front of the Reserve Bank of Australia building in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The Reserve Bank's chief economist says current economic uncertainty, especially around US tariffs, makes forecasting and rate setting more difficult, as Macquarie Bank warns Donald Trump's economic policies run the risk of sparking a stock market crash.

title.children: RBA watching US economy as Macquarie warns of potential share crash

image.altText: Prue Car NSW Minister for Education looks sideways as she stands outdoors at a press conference

props.synopsis: Education Minister Prue Car has rejected suggestions the government is blocking the release of internal documents detailing serious incidents in NSW childcare centres.

title.children: NSW denies blocking internal documents in wake of 4C investigation

image.altText: Bounty offer letter for Kevin Yam

props.synopsis: The federal government has lodged diplomatic protests with China after two prominent Hong Kong activists in Australia were targeted in what appear to be coordinated intimidation campaigns.

title.children: Melbourne residents receive 'wanted' letter for Hong Kong pro-democracy activist

image.altText: A herd of AACo's wagyu heifers at Westholme station in Queensland.

props.synopsis: A theory for their cause of death was that a tap from a water tank to a trough was accidentally off. The deaths have horrified people in the agriculture industry, and marks more turmoil at AACo.

title.children: Two herds of cattle owned by luxury beef giant AACo die in one month

image.altText: Side headshot of WA Premier Roger Cook speaking.

props.synopsis: The huge health portfolio will no longer rest on the shoulders of a single minister following the dramatic WA cabinet reshuffle, but the risk is that problems could fall between the gaps, writes state political reporter Keane Bourke.

title.children: Cabinet overhaul is just the start of Cook stamping his authority on WA

image.altText: A man dressed for freezing conditions hauls a sled across an icy landscape.

props.synopsis: Aaron Crook estimates he got 11 hours sleep in seven days as he trekked 620 kilometres across the Arctic Circle to win one of the world's toughest races.

title.children: Australian man wins Arctic ultra-marathon in gruelling -42 degree conditions

image.altText: Power lines and electricity poles are seen with the Melbourne skyline in the distance on a mostly clear day.

props.synopsis: Households are once again bracing for another round of power bill hikes. But for a nation that is one of the world's biggest energy exporters, it's a situation that defies logic and reeks of an epic policy failure.

title.children: The epic policy failure that's to blame for rising household power bills

image.altText: Martin Dole 2

props.synopsis: In the full Operation Apollo report tabled in parliament, the NT corruption watchdog found that despite persistent "rumours" there was "something suspicious" about Martin Dole's promotion, there was "no basis" to conclude any impropriety.

title.children: Acting NT top cop's appointment to deputy cleared after 'rumours'

image.altText: The Radio Free Asia logo on a wall behind an empty desk.

props.synopsis: A former Chinese state media editor is "delighted" and an ex-Cambodian PM appreciates the Trump administration's decision to slash funding to US-backed media, including Voice of America and Radio Free Asia.

title.children: 'Lie factory': Chinese state media welcomes cuts to US-backed media

image.altText: A boy seen swimming underwater holding a floating board

props.synopsis: Royal Life Saving research shows nearly half of school children entering their teens are failing to attain basic swimming skills, making thousands vulnerable to drowning in adulthood.

title.children: Decline in swimming abilities puts a generation at risk
